petitioner.name: LORENZO PRADO NAVARETTE AND JOSE PRADO NAVARETTE

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: We'll hear argument in Case 12-9490, Navarette v. California. Mr. Kleven.

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: So if the tip -- so if the tip is, is this car is driving by and throwing Alderson Reporting Company bombs out the window, okay, every -- you know, whatever, 500 yards, the police find the car, they have to wait until they see the person actually throw a bomb out the window themselves, before pulling them over?

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: So your answer is yes, the car is going there, and he's throwing a bomb out, and it goes off, but he has to wait till he sees them throw out another bomb?

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: I thought that -- that J.L. gave an example of an exception that the report is somebody is carrying a bomb?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: Throwing bombs doesn't count, but carrying a bomb does, is that it?  Were they throwing bombs that they weren't carrying?

speakers.name: JUSTICE ALITO
speakers.text: Excuse me.  I'm sorry. Could I ask you what you mean by an "anonymous tip"? Suppose somebody calls up 911 and gives a name?  Does that make it not an anonymous tip?

speakers.name: JUSTICE ALITO
speakers.text: Well, how would you corroborate it?  Let's say the person calls up and gives a name and gives an address?  So what would be necessary?  What would the police have to do then before they could stop the vehicle, other than observing the vehicle do something illegal? Alderson Reporting Company

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: Well, what if you have caller ID.  I mean, you have one of these anonymous flip phones, right?  You can buy them, it's prepaid. You call up and say, I'm -- you know, John Smith, I've seen this, and they look, there's the caller, there's the number. Then they can do it.

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: Well, isn't that all caller ID gives you?

speakers.name: JUSTICE ALITO
speakers.text: If we transport the standard that applies outside of the vehicle context to this context, what would happen in this situation?  A person calls up and says, this is my name, this is my address and it's -- it's not blocked by caller ID, so the 911 operator can see that that's the name, that's the address. The person says, this guy ran me off the road.  The police find the vehicle.  They drive behind the vehicle for a while.  They don't -- they don't see any -- they don't see any violation.  So then they think, well, this guy must have lied. Alderson Reporting Company So are they going to prosecute the guy for calling -- calling that in?

speakers.name: JUSTICE ALITO
speakers.text: I mean, your argument goes well beyond.  You're saying this has to do with anonymous tips, but it really goes well beyond anonymous tips.  It covers tips where you know exactly who called in, and what you're saying is that they really can never stop a vehicle no matter what kind of a tip they get, unless they see the vehicle committing an illegal act. That's the argument.

speakers.name: JUSTICE ALITO
speakers.text: Well, give me an example of a situation in which the police can pull somebody over after receiving a tip without actually seeing the vehicle commit an illegal act? Alderson Reporting Company

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: Do we have any indication that this is a serious problem?  The false tips?

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: Well, is that -- is that true?  I mean, how many people die from drunk driving versus how many people dry--die from firearms?

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: I was just going to say, we have held that the -- the standards are loosened in the vehicle context because your expectation of privacy is diminished when you're out on the road driving along in -- in a vehicle.  Does that have any pertinence?

speakers.name: JUSTICE KAGAN
speakers.text: But in the context in which we've approved sobriety checkpoints, why should we get bent out of shape over this?

speakers.name: JUSTICE KAGAN
speakers.text: Well, but why is that an important line?  Why should we be more concerned when an individual automobile is pulled over?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOTOMAYOR
speakers.text: White suggested that we don't have an absolute rule with respect to requiring independent corroboration of the actual illegal conduct. In White, the -- the tipster gave future predictive information, but all of it was innocent, somebody Alderson Reporting Company driving a car and going to a particular place. Now, you're asking us to import that wholesale.  Why don't we just stick to our general standard, which is the totality of the circumstances, and look at what failure there is in the logic of the California court below.  It -- it looked at the quality of the information regarding the vehicle, which is a legitimate tipster will tell you what the vehicle looks like and its license plate or enough information so it can be identified. It looked at the caller actually witnessing the event and giving you enough detail to know that it's not a legal conclusion, but an actual event that suggests recklessness, and a corroboration of the -- of the details given by the tipster. Isn't that the application of our traditional test?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOTOMAYOR
speakers.text: Well, that's just not true in Florida v. J.L. because the individual didn't match the description completely, and there were two or three individuals there, not just one, and so -- and there was no predictive or no other detail, other than someone in this general area. Alderson Reporting Company

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: Correct me if -- if I'm wrong.  I might be missing something.  The tip in J.L. was not a -- did not assert that a crime was being committed, so there was something suspicious.  There was no crime in possession of the gun.  Or correct me if I'm wrong.

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: But -- but here -- here, there was -- the report was a crime.  Or is that not a correct distinction?

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: Well --

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: And it was illegal.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: It was illegal.

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: But -- but the tip, in and of itself, did not indicate that a crime was being committed, which is different from this case.

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: No, I'm talking about an interpretation of what the tip said.

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: No, a Terry stop.

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: You might have had grounds for a Terry stop.

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: Well, I -- I think there's a difference, but I think, for our purposes, we can Alderson Reporting Company assume that the cases are comparable in that respect --

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: -- but not comparable, perhaps, in others.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOTOMAYOR
speakers.text: No reason to believe the caller had personal knowledge.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOTOMAYOR
speakers.text: No reason to believe the person had personal knowledge.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOTOMAYOR
speakers.text: He didn't say that the gun was pulled on him or that -- or how he saw it or how he knew.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOTOMAYOR
speakers.text: So you don't think there's something significant about calling up and saying, someone forced me off the road?

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: What if there's no way for the officer to corroborate the allegation?  You know, you see -- see somebody on the street grab a young child, throw her in the trunk of the car, and then take off. And somebody calls with an anonymous tip saying, this fellow -- you know, in this car, has got a child in the trunk.  The police can follow the person -- you know, for hours and they're not going to see any corroborating evidence. Can they pull that car over?

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: So just -- your answer in that case is that the police cannot pull that car over?

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: Well, let's expand it a little bit.  It's a -- it's a one-lane -- two-lane road going down, but it merges into -- you know, an eight-lane expressway.  You have one police car.  It's going to be hard for that police car to maintain surveillance.  And you say they've just got to let them go.

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: Well, just in terms of your position, do you think they could pull the car over?

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: Really?  Okay.

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: You get an A for consistency.  I'm -- I'm not sure about common sense. (Laughter.)

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: I'm -- I'm not sure he gets an A for consistency.  I thought -- I thought you said you acknowledged or didn't repudiate the statement in -- in our opinion in J.L., that, if there was a bomb in the car, that would be something else. What -- what if there's in the car -- the tip is this person has an atomic bomb given him by Al Qaeda; he is driving it into the center of Los Angeles to -- to eradicate the entire city, okay? Let it go?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: He tells you the license number, where the car is.  You can't stop the car?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: So you see, he's not Alderson Reporting Company consistent.  I mean --

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: So the -- the atomic bomb, the level of danger is great enough, but the young girl in the trunk, the level of danger is not great enough?

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: What is your position what you would do if you were on this Court, with those hypotheticals?  What is your position that should happen in those two hypotheticals?

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: What is your position as to what the Court should do in those cases?

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: I understand it, but we're interested in a hypothetical.

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: What about this:  In J.L., the Court made quite a point of saying, "An accurate description of a subject's readily observable location is reliable in a limited -- limited sense, namely, identifying the person.  Such a tip, however, does not show that the tipster has knowledge of concealed criminal activity."

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: All right.  Not concealed here.

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: So that's an obvious Alderson Reporting Company difference.  I mean, one case, it was concealed; this case, it isn't concealed.  What do you say?

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: Didn't -- didn't the tip here have something to do with his driving around in a wild way -- or at least an unusual way?  I'm not sure I would have followed him, if it had been me.  Anyway, you see the point.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: It seems to me you're willing to accept our allowing -- or allowing the police to stop the car with the atom bomb and even allowing the police to stop the car with the kidnapped girl in the trunk. Once -- you know, once you give away those, Alderson Reporting Company we're just arguing about details, where you draw the line.  Does -- does drunken driving fall on one side or the other of the line, and some of us may think drunken driving is -- is pretty serious and probably -- you know, as serious as having a kidnapped girl in the trunk.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: Okay.  More than that, I want you to say the Court shouldn't.  Let the car go. Bye-bye, Los Angeles.

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: In this case, your -- your grade for consistency depends on this answer. (Laughter.)

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: Your grade for consistency depends on this answer.

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: But -- that's why I asked you, and I pressed the point a little bit, because in the beginning of your brief, it says that the anonymous tip, what did you say, indicated that a Ford F-150 pickup truck had run someone off the road.

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: Now, maybe you do have to be known specially whether the person's drunk or not, but you don't have to have some special knowledge of anything concealed to know if somebody has run somebody off the road.

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: Even if the person weren't drunk, I think it's illegal to run someone else off the road. (Laughter.)

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: No.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: And I assume you would -- you would also say, to tie it into Justice Breyer's question, you would also say that that tip, "Somebody ran me off the road," would not justify the court -- the police in stopping the car, just to make sure that this car was not the one that drove the guy off the road, right?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: Never mind drunkenness. The tip doesn't say anything about drunkenness.  It just said, this car drove me off the road.  You'd say the police could not follow that car, pull him over, and -- and ask did you -- did you drive somebody off the road?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: Following the car is going to do them no good as to whether he drove -- drove somebody off the road.  They're not looking for a drunk. Alderson Reporting Company They're looking for somebody who drove somebody off the road, right?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: They could if the guy admitted it, you know.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: They could play Mutt and Jeff with him and he -- oh, yeah, I did, yes.

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: Well, but you -- what if -- what if the person said, okay, my name is this -- you know, my phone number is this; this guy drove me off the road.  They can't corroborate that until they stop the guy.  Or you're saying they have to? They have to wait, they have to make the call, see if the guy is there.  Are you the guy that just called?  So that guy's got to talk on his cell phone while he's driving. Alderson Reporting Company

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: Thank you, counsel. Mr. Laurence.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOTOMAYOR
speakers.text: Is every reckless driving drunk driving?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOTOMAYOR
speakers.text: Is every reckless driving drunk driving?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOTOMAYOR
speakers.text: How about if somebody just calls and says, X vehicle is driving recklessly, says no more, doesn't describe how, doesn't give you any details as to how they know it.  Is that enough for reasonable suspicion?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: But not necessarily drunkenness.  I think there -- there are a lot of people that get tickets for reckless driving who have not served jail terms for driving drunk.  The two are far from synonymous.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOTOMAYOR
speakers.text: Why?  How about speeding?  There's plenty of people who speed regularly.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOTOMAYOR
speakers.text: Isn't that reckless behavior?  So how do you know someone who calls -- my mother, who can't drive above 50, thinks that, when I go 51, that I'm speeding and reckless.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: And -- and between the, what, 50 and 75 percent, they've stopped people without just cause.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: Or they've -- they've troubled people who shouldn't have been troubled.

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: What -- what if the call is -- you know, I'm driving, this guy just drove by me, I looked over, he didn't have his seatbelt on.  I mean, can the police pull that guy over?

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: Well yeah, there are laws against driving without a seatbelt because that protects people's lives.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: Well, reckless driving always does, whether it -- whether it's the consequence of inebriation or not.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: So a simple call saying, boy, this guy -- you know, he cut in, in front of me. He's changing lanes too frequently --

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: -- that -- that enables the policeman, without observing any of that reckless driving, to stop the car further down the road.

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: I've never understood -- what good do those -- you know, let's say that I'm at a party, I don't like somebody there.  I see they have a couple of drinks.  I know what kind of car he drives.  I know the -- I can look at the license plate. I call -- you know, ten minutes later.        I know where he goes driving home.  There's this car. It's a white whatever.  It's got this license plate. Alderson Reporting Company It's swerving all over the road.

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: Whether he is or not, the police go up, they pull him over and find out, yeah -- you know, he fails the breathalyzer, and I get my revenge.

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: My question --

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: I was just going to say my point is it need not necessarily be a personal observation of the person operating the car.  It may be prior knowledge.  And I gather one of the issues we're concerned about is people using this to -- you know, exact revenge or -- or do something else having nothing to do with whether or not the person is violating the law on the highway.

speakers.name: JUSTICE KAGAN
speakers.text: If I understand you correctly, as long as you can identify the car, you need no specificity as to what the car has actually done.  In other words -- you know, just saying the driver was reckless is enough.  Is that -- is that correct?

speakers.name: JUSTICE KAGAN
speakers.text: What would fail your test?

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: Yes.  But you're just saying -- I mean, but his basic point is, on the other side, is these are all variations of the famous white Alderson Reporting Company horse defense.  You don't know the -- the white horse defense?  Your Honor, my client was innocent because, at the time of the crime, he was in Yugoslavia wearing a white horse -- riding a white horse. And to prove it, I have the horse here in court.  You see?  I mean, you can't -- it's bootstrapping to put it more succinctly.  All you know is that somebody came in and quoted -- and said there was a crime.  And that's all you know.  And now -- now when -- when are instances where no more than the report that it's a crime, that's reasonable suspicion. That's -- give me some other instances where the courts have upheld, well, that's enough.

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: I'm not saying common sense.  I'm saying what the courts have held.  Sorry. (Laughter.)

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: Not a bare--, a description that a crime is occurring, where has -- that's all, I mean, and -- and then we have a question of, well, is it in the one category or the other? Because what we have here, someone phones in and says, a crime is occurring. Alderson Reporting Company And -- and we know, we've corroborated the following.  If a crime was occurring, he was in a position to know because he can define -- he can talk about the white horse, or he can talk about the car.

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: Well, correct me if I'm wrong, but my recollection of Hensley is, you're right, the police department 1 notifies police department 2. But a premise of the case, I had thought, was that police department 1 had reasonable suspicion.

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: I understand that.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOTOMAYOR
speakers.text: Hensley's victim wasn't a victim; meaning there was -- it was an anonymous tip?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOTOMAYOR
speakers.text: Yeah, that's what I'm saying.  So it wasn't an anonymous tip?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOTOMAYOR
speakers.text: It wasn't public safety. It was the report of a crime by a known person.

speakers.name: JUSTICE KAGAN
speakers.text: And, Mr. Laurence, do I understand what you're saying?  You're saying that in every case when we have to decide whether the threshold Alderson Reporting Company level of reasonable suspicion has been met or whether the level of probable cause has been met, that courts can take into account the seriousness of the offense, and what would not count as probable cause for one crime will count as probable cause for another?  Is that what you're saying?

speakers.name: JUSTICE KAGAN
speakers.text: Well, I don't understand how what you're saying is different from what I just said, and that would seem to me to work quite a substantial change in -- in Fourth Amendment law, that when we decide whether reasonable suspicion exists, when -- whether probable cause exists, that we get to take into account how serious the offense is.

speakers.name: JUSTICE KAGAN
speakers.text: The balancing occurs categorically.  We decide that there's a reasonable suspicion standard by balancing interests.  What we don't do is say -- you know, depending on how serious we think this crime is, more or less will meet that reasonable suspicion standard. That would be a very substantial reworking of Fourth Amendment law -- or so it seems to me.  Maybe I'm wrong.

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: Could you explain to me one more time why it's relevant that there were these details that it was a particular kind of crime, that it was silver, the license plate, that's this case. Suppose in another case, a car just ran me off the road, and it's the only -- the only car that's on Highway 1 between Fort Bragg and the state park.

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: And incidentally -- it doesn't have much to do with the case -- is this a two -- a two-lane road?

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: That's what I thought.

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: There's a tip that someone is carrying a concealed weapon, and we have held that that has to be corroborated -- corroborated.  You can take out a concealed weapon in an instant and fire it and kill lots of people.  In fact, it was pointed out that there are more deaths caused by guns than there are from drunk driving. So what's the difference?        The -- the argument on the drunk driving is very, very dangerous, but so is having a gun in one's pocket.

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: But if you -- once -- once you brandish it, it's too late.  The damage will be caused.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: Of course, this call didn't say, I think the guy was drunk.  It just said, somebody drove -- you know, drove me off the road.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: Right?  So this isn't -- it isn't a call that says there's a drunken driver.  It's just a call that says somebody drove irresponsibly, right?  And that's enough to stop them.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: Okay.  Really irresponsibly, okay?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: Really irresponsibly.

speakers.name: JUSTICE KAGAN
speakers.text: So do you think, Mr. Laurence, if the police had followed this man for Alderson Reporting Company half an hour and seen no other signs of erratic driving and nobody can drunk drive -- can drive drunk for half an hour without swerving, without doing something else. So they could still have stopped the car?

speakers.name: JUSTICE KAGAN
speakers.text: Well, I thought you were saying as long as somebody had -- had given an account that, some time ago, he had driven another driver off -- he had run another driver off the road, doesn't matter whether you're drunk, doesn't matter anything, there was an account of an illegal act taking place, and that was enough to stop him.  It doesn't matter what he's doing now.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: It wasn't a report of drunk driving.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: Somebody ran me off the road.  Somebody was driving really irresponsibly.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: That's enough to stop him down the road.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: What about cutting me off too quickly, you know?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: Cuts right in front of me. Really ticks me off. (Laughter.)

speakers.name: JUSTICE ALITO
speakers.text: Well, how would somebody -- how would somebody ever be able -- who observes another car driving ever be able to say that person was drunk? All they could -- all they could observe is what they see.  They don't know whether the person -- what is causing that kind of behavior.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: I think it's an entirely different case if the tip -- if the tip here was -- you know, I was at a party, this guy got in his car, he Alderson Reporting Company should not have turned the key on in that car, this guy is really drunk, you should stop that car on the road. I think that's totally different from somebody just saying, this guy swerved, or this guy drove me off the road.  You're -- you're just making the assumption that -- that every -- every one of those incidents demonstrates a drunk behind the wheel, and I just don't think that's true.

speakers.name: JUSTICE ALITO
speakers.text: Well, why is it limited to drunk driving?  I don't understand that.  I've been -- I've been on an expressway, and I've had people go by me at -- they went by in a blur.  They must have been going well over a hundred miles an hour. Now, if the police catch up with that person, of course, the person's going to slow down while the police follow the person.  And then when the police decide to stop, they're going to go back to engaging in this intentional, extremely dangerous conduct. So I don't understand why there's a distinction between reporting that somebody necessarily is driving erratically, so the person may be impaired, Alderson Reporting Company and somebody who is -- where you have extremely reckless driving that's intentional.

speakers.name: JUSTICE KAGAN
speakers.text: But all crime represents a threat to public safety, and yet, we have these standards.

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: Why?  Why -- the -- we have the case of the trusted informer.  The informer several times has given the police tips and it turned Alderson Reporting Company out to be right.  And then we have another side, the anonymous person.  Then there's somebody who calls, gives a correct name and address, but no record at all of reliability. Why should the fact that the name is known -- the name of the informant is known, if the police have no reason to believe one way or another that this informer is reliable?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: You don't think that a teenager standing on a street corner with a couple of Alderson Reporting Company other teenagers with a gun in his belt represents a threat to public safety?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: No?  All right.

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: Thank you, counsel. No, no.        We're going to hear from Ms. Kovner first. Ms. Kovner.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOTOMAYOR
speakers.text: All right.  Please define for me what behavior would give police officers or what descriptors would be adequate for the police to think someone's drunk.  Swerving, I know, has been mentioned.  But reckless driving, there's been a lot of discussion that there could be a wide variety of Alderson Reporting Company reckless driving.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOTOMAYOR
speakers.text: What -- what other things would a -- would a caller have to say?

speakers.name: JUSTICE KAGAN
speakers.text: Well, what -- what goes on the other side of the line?  I mean, why -- why is this on one side?  And then tell me what's on the other.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOTOMAYOR
speakers.text: I think what you're saying to me, am I correct, that almost any moving violation counts?  Changing a lane without a signal, which seems to be endemic in Washington, but -- (Laughter.)

speakers.name: JUSTICE KAGAN
speakers.text: How about somebody cutting someone off in their lane?

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: Well, where does that -- I think this is the question Justice Kagan asked earlier -- how does the nature of the offense affect the reasonableness of the suspicion?

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: I mean, in either case, you have -- let's say the seatbelt and the swerving driver.  It's the same witness.  He said, still, it's a white Ford.  The reasonableness of the suspicion would seem, to me, to be totally divorced from what it's about.

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: Well, that's just not true.  It's -- it's an acquaintance, I know what kind of car he drives, I know where he's going.  I didn't see anything on the road, but I call the police and say, oh, there's this -- you know, white Ford swerving all over the road.

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: No, I'm talking Alderson Reporting Company about the concern that you want to have the police pull over people that you don't like, where you know somebody's got something bad in the car, and you don't like it, and so you're going to take advantage of the fact that the police don't have to observe anything, and yet, you can still get them to pull over this person.

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: Why is that different from the knowledge in J.L., that they were three young men, and they were described, and the caller said, "The one with the gun is the one with the plaid shirt."  All of that was corroborated by the police, and yet, we held that that was no indication that a crime had been committed.

speakers.name: JUSTICE KAGAN
speakers.text: But then you think J.L. would have come out differently if the tipster had said, "I just saw these guys and I saw -- you know, one of them had a gun"?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: Yeah, but that -- but that second danger -- you may have a drunken driver on the road; that danger can be eliminated by following the car.  You don't have to stop the car right away.  You can follow it and if, indeed, the driver seems to be driving erratically, then you can stop.  You'd have probable cause. Alderson Reporting Company I don't think you have to automatically allow a stop in order to prevent all of the horribles that are going to arise from drunk driving.  Follow the car.  If he's behaving like a drunk driver, then stop him.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: That is so remote.  I mean, it seems to me you're asking us to adopt a broad rule that is contrary to what we normally do for searches and seizures because, now and then, it would seem, to me, very rarely, before the police can stop the drunk driver, he kills somebody. I mean, I suppose that could happen now and then but it's pretty fanciful.

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: But here, we have the police did follow the vehicle for about 5 miles and saw nothing erratic about the driving.  So perhaps, if the police had immediately stopped the person or -- but don't -- don't we have to take account that there was no corroboration?  When the police get there.  Even if they could stop him instantly, when they have no corroboration, then that doesn't amount to reasonable suspicion.

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: I don't know if we have to get into the drunk driving.  It's 3 miles south of the Alderson Reporting Company Humboldt County border on -- do you know the answer to this?  Is it in the record?  I mean, on many sections of that road, in Mendocino County, you drive someone off the road, they are dead. I mean, there are sheer drops, and so I just wonder, if I look that up here, what's the situation where this supposedly took place?

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: What about the danger from the police side?  In other words, they know -- or they suspect that the guy driving the white car has a lot of marijuana in the trunk.  They have no basis for pulling him over.  And they say, well, guess what, we got an anonymous tip that he was driving erratically, so we pulled him over.

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: What protection is there against that? Alderson Reporting Company

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: Thank you, counsel. Mr. Kleven, you have 3 minutes remaining.

speakers.name: JUSTICE ALITO
speakers.text: Well, I find that unsatisfactory because if you -- unless you're willing to say, it doesn't matter whether it's a bomb, an atomic Alderson Reporting Company bomb, a little bomb, then there -- there must be -- if you're going to draw the line someplace, then you're going to have to distinguish between those reports of crimes that are serious enough to be on one side of the line and those reports of a crime that are not serious enough to be on that side of the line. You either have to go all the way, or you have to draw a line, and if you're going to draw a line, I would like to know where the line is.

speakers.name: JUSTICE ALITO
speakers.text: All right.  Forget about reasonable suspicion.  Just can it be done?

speakers.name: JUSTICE ALITO
speakers.text: You can say it can never done, even if it's an atomic bomb, even if it's some other type of bomb.  You can say that.  Or you can say, no, there's a line someplace.  If you're going to say there's a line someplace, then, really, I think you need to tell us where the line is.

speakers.name: JUSTICE ALITO
speakers.text: For a bomb.  For any kind of a bomb?

speakers.name: JUSTICE ALITO
speakers.text: It has to be a big bomb.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: What about drawing the line at intentional conduct?  The guy who has a bomb is going to use it.  He's intentionally going to use it.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: Or maybe intentionally doing an action that is going to harm more than one person, as opposed to, hmm, maybe this person might accidentally, because he's inub-- inebriated, hurt somebody? It seems to me there's a clear line between somebody who's -- who's bent on an intentional crime and somebody who might harm somebody because of his conduct. You like that one? Alderson Reporting Company

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: Yes, I have another one, too.

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: So somebody has five drinks and goes and gets in the car, that's not intentionally trying to harm someone?  Or recklessly trying to harm --

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: Thank you, counsel.

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: Counsel. The case is submitted.
